Introduction

A wide range of complications can occur hours to years after solid organ transplantation.  They can impair allograft function (eg, acute rejection) or systemic recipient health (eg, opportunistic infections).  Solid organ transplant complications can be classified as (

):



  • Immunologic
  • Infectious
  • Noninfectious


This article details these 3 types of complications, then presents a timeline-based differential diagnosis for clinical practice.  Kidney, heart, and lung transplants are used as examples, but the principles also apply to other solid organ (eg, liver, pancreas) transplants.

Immunologic complications



Solid organ graft rejection is classified as hyperacute, acute, or chronic (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
).

Hyperacute rejection (minutes to hours after transplant)



  • Preformed recipient antibodies immediately attack antigens expressed on the graft vascular endothelium (eg, human leukocyte antigens [HLA], ABO antigens).  Prior recipient sensitization (eg, previous blood transfusions, multiparity) is the main risk factor.  Upon antibody attack, massive complement activation results in acute fibrinoid necrosis of the vessel wall and intravascular thrombosis, leading to necrosis and graft loss.
  • Hyperacute rejection is almost always observed intraoperatively.  The graft appears dusky and mottled, and patients are typically systemically ill (eg, massive inflammatory response).  The graft should typically be immediately explanted.
  • Most cases are prevented with careful HLA matching prior to transplantation (eg, directed donation from a relative with identical or haploidentical HLA (
    figure 1
    ).  When seeking random donors (eg, if no family members are available), measuring the reactivity of the organ recipient's serum against the population's antigen pool (panel-reactive antibody [PRA] levels) can help determine the risk for hyperacute rejection.

Acute rejection (usually <6 months)



  • Acute cellular rejection (ACR) is by far the most common form of acute rejection.  It involves recipient T cells becoming sensitized against donor antigens.  Histology shows a lymphocytic infiltration into the graft parenchyma (
    image 1
    ).  Acute antibody-mediated rejection (ABMR), a less common form of acute rejection, involves recipient B cells becoming sensitized against donor antigens (mainly HLA), with the resultant donor-specific antibodies fixing complement in the vascular endothelium.  Histology shows endovascular C4b staining and microvascular inflammation.
  • Infection (eg, spillage of immunogenic contents) is a major risk factor.  Patients have constitutional symptoms (eg, fever, malaise) and/or develop organ-specific symptoms (eg, kidney-specific symptoms: hypertension, azotemia, oliguria, proteinuria Â± glomerular microhematuria; lung-specific symptoms: dyspnea, cough, hypoxemia; heart-specific symptoms: heart failure, arrhythmias, echocardiographic abnormalities).
  • Management of acute rejection involves intensifying immunosuppression.  Because ACR involves T-cell sensitization, intravenous glucocorticoids (and in refractory cases, T-cell depletion therapy) are helpful.  ABMR (B-cell sensitization) is typically treated with plasmapheresis, intravenous immunoglobulin, and B-cell depletion therapy (eg, rituximab [anti-CD20]).  Routine biopsies are typically performed beginning after transplant (eg, every few months for the first year) to detect subclinical acute rejection.

Chronic rejection (usually >12 months after transplant)



  • Chronic lymphocytic inflammation leads to fibrosis and obliteration of allograft structures (eg, airways, blood vessels).  Specific syndromes are based on the transplanted organ (eg, lung: bronchiolitis obliterans syndrome; heart: cardiac allograft vasculopathy with intimal hyperplasia diffuse narrowing of distal coronary arteries (
    image 2
    ).
  • A biopsy is almost always required (mainly to differentiate from acute rejection), and management depends on the specific syndrome (eg, sirolimus to block coronary myofibroblast proliferation in cardiac allograft vasculopathy).  As a last resort, retransplantation may be necessary.


Preventing all forms of acute and chronic rejection involves long-term immunosuppression using multiple immunosuppressive agents.  The most common first-line 3-drug maintenance regimen consists of (

figure 2
):



  • A glucocorticoid (eg, prednisone)
  • A calcineurin inhibitor (CNI) (eg, tacrolimus)
  • An antimetabolite (eg, mycophenolate mofetil)

Infectious complications



Approximately 50% of solid organ transplant recipients are hospitalized for a serious infection (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
) within the first 6 months after transplant.  Infection rate is highest for transplants in which the organ is constantly exposed to the environment (eg, lung transplant).  Infections increase the risk for rejection.

Early infections (<1 month after transplant):  Nosocomial pathogens



Infections in the first few weeks after transplant mostly relate to the hospitalization process.  They include ventilator-associated or hospital-acquired pneumonia, bacteremia (eg, due to indwelling venous catheters), surgical site infections, and Clostridioides difficile.  Nosocomial pathogens include methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, vancomycin-resistant enterococci, and extended-spectrum beta-lactamase gram-negative bacteria (eg, Klebsiella, Enterobacteriaceae).

Intermediate infections (1-12 months after transplant):  Opportunistic pathogens



Intermediate infectious complications occur during the period of peak immunosuppression, resulting in opportunistic infections.  Key opportunistic infections include:



Cytomegalovirus (CMV)



CMV is a latent (episomal) herpesvirus present in approximately 60% of donors and recipients.  Upon immunosuppression, CMV can reactivate from donor or recipient tissue reservoirs, causing tissue damage to the graft or distant organs.  The highest risk for reactivation is posed when the donor is seropositive (D+) and the recipient is seronegative (Râˆ’) based on CMV IgG (ie, the recipient has no preexisting immunity).



CMV reactivation ranges from asymptomatic viremia (positive blood PCR or IgM seroconversion) to acute viral syndrome (ie, viremia, fever, malaise, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia) and tissue-invasive disease (eg, viral syndrome + organ dysfunction).  Almost any organ can be involved in invasive disease (eg, colitis, esophagitis, retinitis, pneumonitis).



Invasive CMV disease is treated with several weeks of intravenous antiviral drugs (eg, ganciclovir, foscarnet).  Because of the risk for reactivation, which can precipitate rejection, most transplant recipients are prescribed long-term CMV prophylaxis (eg, valganciclovir).



Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PJP)



P jirovecii is a commensal fungus that exists at very low levels in lungs of healthy hosts without causing clinical disease.  However, it proliferates upon suppression of cellular immunity.  Patients who undergo a lung transplant have the higest risk of PJP.  PJP presents with subacute (ie, weeks) fever and dyspnea, severe hypoxemia, and diffuse bilateral ground glass and interstitial opacities (

image 3
).  First-line treatment is trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole, with alternatives (eg, if necessary due to a sulfa allergy) including atovaquone or clindamycin plus primaquine.  Systemic corticosteroids are indicated for hypoxemia (SaO2 <92% on room air).  Long-term PJP prophylaxis (eg, trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole, dapsone) is indicated for all patients on immunosuppressive therapy.



Other opportunistic infections



  • Invasive pulmonary aspergillosis:  characterized by hemoptysis, necrotizing pneumonia, positive galactomannan
  • Tuberculosis and nontuberculous mycobacteria:  characterized by constitutional symptoms, upper lobe cavitation, and positive acid-fast bacilli stain; lymphadenopathy may be absent and interferon gamma release assay may be unreliable due to immunosuppression
  • Nocardia and Actinomycetes:  characterized by pulmonary nodules and brain abscess


A high degree of suspicion for infections is necessary.  Patients with immunosuppression do not mount a full inflammatory response (eg, leukocyte count might be only slightly elevated).  In addition, patients who have undergone a lung transplant may have surprisingly minimal respiratory symptoms due to sensory denervation.

Late infections (>12 months after transplant):  Community-acquired pathogens



Late infections mirror those of the general population.  Community-acquired pneumonia (eg, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, Mycoplasma) and respiratory viruses (eg, influenza, respiratory syncytial virus, rhinovirus) are the most common infections.  Although patient microbiology is similar among those who are immunocompetent and those who are immunocompromised, patients who are immunocompromised are approximately 8 times as likely to develop an infection, tend to be more severely ill, and tend to have infections that are protracted.

Noninfectious complications

Early graft dysfunction



After transplant, there is often a short period of time (several days) before the donor organ "wakes up."  This early graft dysfunction (eg, presenting as pulmonary edema, oliguria) occurs due to an ischemia-reperfusion injury that causes inflammation and oxidative stress and may require temporary intensive support (eg, lung-protective ventilation, hemodialysis).  In patients with a lung transplant, early graft dysfunction is referred to as primary graft dysfunction (PGD).  In patients with a kidney transplant, it is referred to as delayed graft function (DGF).  Risk factors include prolonged ischemia and having a cadaveric (vs brain-dead) donor.  Although most cases resolve spontaneously over the first week, PGD and DGF are associated with negative long-term outcomes such as acute and chronic rejection.



Anastomotic dehiscence can also lead to early graft failure.  In patients with a kidney transplant, a donor graft ultrasonography can detect vascular and ureteral dehiscence.  In patients with a lung transplant, the bronchial anastomosis is monitored with bronchoscopy.  Breakdown of the bronchial anastomosis leads to bronchopleural fistula (pneumothorax and large air leak).

Drug toxicities



Patients who have undergone an organ transplant are exposed to long courses of relatively toxic medications.  Most patients are on a 3-drug regimen consisting of a glucocorticoid, a CNI, and an antimetabolite.



  • Glucocorticoid (eg, prednisone) toxicity:  Chronic exposure to glucocorticoids is associated with hyperglycemia (~25% of patients develop type 2 diabetes mellitus), osteoporosis, adrenal suppression, and cataract formation.
  • CNI (eg, tacrolimus, cyclosporine) toxicity:  The most common adverse effect of CNIs is CNI nephrotoxicity due to renal vasoconstriction.  The characteristic histologic finding is renal tubular vacuolization (
    image 4
    ).  CNI nephrotoxicity can be mitigated by monitoring serum trough drug levels.  CNIs can also cause neurotoxicity (eg, tremors, encephalopathy).  The renal and neurologic toxicity of CNIs is likely due to disruption of intracellular calcium signaling.
  • Antimetabolite (eg, mycophenolate, azathioprine) toxicity:  Common adverse effects of antimetabolites include myelosuppression (eg, leukopenia) and gastrointestinal intolerance (eg, diarrhea).

Malignancies



The risk for all malignancies is increased after organ transplant due to immunosuppression.  Nonmelanoma skin cancers (NMSCs) and posttransplant lymphoproliferative disorder (PTLD) are the most common.



  • NMSCs:  Squamous and basal cell carcinoma risk is approximately 75-fold higher than the general population.  Of all the organs, skin has one of the highest rates of genomic damage and turnover.  Prevention (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 4
    ) involves ultraviolet protection (eg, using sunblock, wearing long sleeves) and having an annual skin check.
  • PTLD:  Reactivation of Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) can transform B cells, resulting in clonal proliferation.  The main risk factor is EBV D+/Râˆ’ serostatus (ie, no previous immunity).  PTLD presents with B symptoms (eg, fever, night sweats, weight loss), bulky lymphadenopathy, and organ dysfunction, which depends on the affected site (eg, lung or brain mass).

Clinical approach



For patients presenting with worsening graft function or systemic issues, the differential diagnosis is typically built around a timeline.

Immediate (<1 day)



Postoperative graft dysfunction is mainly due to ischemia-reperfusion injury (ie, PGD/DGF), surgical anastomotic complications, or hyperacute rejection (rare).

Acute (<1 month)



  • Graft dysfunction is most likely due to residual PGD/DGF and anastomotic dehiscence.  Acute rejection is uncommon during this period because sensitization takes several weeks.
  • Infections are typically caused by hospital-acquired pathogens (eg, Klebsiella).

Post-acute (1-12 months)



  • Graft dysfunction is mainly due to acute rejection (in the first 6 months).
  • Infections are typically caused by opportunistic pathogens (eg, CMV, PJP, Toxoplasma).  Latent viral reactivation (eg, EBV) mainly occurs during this time frame.

Chronic (>12 months)



  • Graft dysfunction is mainly due to chronic rejection (or recurrent episodes of acute rejection).
  • Primary recurrence occurs further out from transplant (>2 years).  Recurrence is more likely with systemic conditions such as focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (kidney), sarcoidosis (lung), and hepatitis C cirrhosis (liver).
  • BK virus nephropathy, a unique cause of chronic renal allograft dysfunction, is due to the reactivation of BK virus, a polyomavirus that lies dormant in the lower urinary tract.


Drug-drug interactions are common (eg, acute kidney injury due to supratherapeutic CNI levels when taking antifungals) and can occur at any time.  Drug toxicities (eg, CNI nephropathy) and secondary malignancies tend to emerge in the >12 months after transplant.

Summary



Solid organ (eg, kidney, lung, heart, liver, pancreas) transplantation is associated with immunologic, infectious, and noninfectious complications.



  • Immunologic complications include hyperacute (eg, preformed antibodies, intraoperative graft necrosis), acute (eg, T- or B-cell sensitization, lymphocytic infiltration), and chronic rejection (eg, fibrosis of graft structures).  Importantly, acute rejection can occur at any time and is triggered by any process that causes graft antigen exposure (eg, infections, Cytomegalovirus reactivation).
  • Infectious complications can arise due to various pathogens, including nosocomial pathogens (eg, can cause ventilator-associated pneumonia) in the early period (<1 month), opportunistic pathogens (eg, Cytomegalovirus and Pneumocystis jirovecii) in the intermediate period (1-12 months), and community-acquired pathogens (eg, Streptococcus pneumoniae) in the late period (>12 months).  Typical infectious symptoms, such as fever and leukocytosis, may be blunted.
  • Noninfectious complications include early ischemia-reperfusion injury, manifesting as delayed graft function.  Important drug toxicities include nephrotoxicity from calcineurin inhibitors and metabolic syndrome from glucocorticoids.  Malignancy risk is elevated due to immunosuppression, especially for nonmelanoma skin cancers and posttransplant lymphoproliferative disorder.
